commits.message: start work on a pds implementation

issue.title: Account creation doesnt take a DID as an input
issue.body: In looking over the API I noticed that `com.atproto.account.create` doesnt take a DID as an input, I guess the assumption is that the PDS will create a DID for the user through the PLC server in the backend? I think its very important that the user can come to a PDS with their own DID and register an account somehow.

issue.title: Lexicon tweaks: encoding and union $type discriminators
issue.body:
Two more Lexicon updates to accommodate stricter programming languages:

- LexXrpcBody `.encoding` is now always a `string`. If multiple encodings must be specified, use a comma-separated list.
- Union discriminators
  - The `union` type now only supports object-values with a `$type` field.
  - The `$type` field must specify the lexicon ID being used.
  - The `union` def now has a `closed` field which, if true, will fail validation if a `$type` is provided which does not match the enumerated refs.

comment.body: @pfrazee last question for clarity, the union `$type` will *always* be fully qualified?

issue.title: Lexicon tweaks: encoding and union $type discriminators
issue.body:
Two more Lexicon updates to accommodate stricter programming languages:

- LexXrpcBody `.encoding` is now always a `string`. If multiple encodings must be specified, use a comma-separated list.
- Union discriminators
  - The `union` type now only supports object-values with a `$type` field.
  - The `$type` field must specify the lexicon ID being used.
  - The `union` def now has a `closed` field which, if true, will fail validation if a `$type` is provided which does not match the enumerated refs.

issue.body:
Two more Lexicon updates to accommodate stricter programming languages:

- LexXrpcBody `.encoding` is now always a `string`. If multiple encodings must be specified, use a comma-separated list.
- Union discriminators
  - The `union` type now only supports object-values with a `$type` field.
  - The `$type` field must specify the lexicon ID being used.
  - The `union` def now has a `closed` field which, if true, will fail validation if a `$type` is provided which does not match the enumerated refs.

comment.body:
Shouldnt media on feed.getPostThread also have a type field?
```diff
diff --git a/lexicons/app/bsky/feed/getPostThread.json b/lexicons/app/bsky/feed/getPostThread.json
index 0bf365d..8922767 100644
--- a/lexicons/app/bsky/feed/getPostThread.json
+++ b/lexicons/app/bsky/feed/getPostThread.json
@@ -33,6 +33,7 @@
       "type": "object",
       "required": ["uri", "cid", "author", "record", "replyCount", "repostCount", "upvoteCount", "downvoteCount", "indexedAt"],
       "properties": {
+        "type": {"type": "string", "const": "post"},
         "uri": {"type": "string"},
         "cid": {"type": "string"},
         "author": {"type": "ref", "ref": "app.bsky.actor.ref#withInfo"},
```

issue.title: Misc Lexicon issues
issue.body:
In working on lexicon codegen i've come across a number of weird potential-bugs:

- com.atproto.sync.getRepo has its output type as cbor, but the output is actually a car file
- notification.updateSeen has output type defined with an encoding but no type definition
- repo.batchWrite has a oneOf schema definition that has inlined type declarations instead of using defs. This might be okay, but its the only place this occurs (and i've lazily assumed its the rule)
- The following lexicons have improperly defined input or output types:
  - account.delete
  - account.get
  - repo.batchWrite
  - session.delete

commits.message: more work on lexgen, can mostly generate server stubs now

issue.title: Likes got replaced by Upvotes/Downvotes
issue.body:
**Edit** There has been extensive discussion about this topic in the Matrix and I think the core team is on the same wavelength with the concerns described below, though the direction remains unclear.

I noticed that likes in the protocol were recently replaced with upvotes/downvotes. This could completely change the purpose and direction of the protocol in a way that makes it no longer viable as a decentralized Twitter-like network.

Tldr: imagine every tweet you make also becomes a Reddit thread, and every reply also shows up in a Reddit comment section.

Upvotes and downvotes will make ATP more fit for reddit-esque discussion boards rather than timeline-based social networking/microblogging. Visually representing a voting score would cause malicious interactions and sheep-like behavior (i.e. downvoting a post just because it's trending towards a negative score).

In the matrix channel there was a reply saying it's up to the client application to work with downvotes if they choose. The problem with this is it would cause a discrepancy with how likes/votes are displayed per client (i.e. one shows the `upvoteCount` as Likes while another shows a positive or negative score based on total upvotes and downvotes accumulated) thus cause constant confusion.

People will make troll replies/downvotes when they see a post that has a lot of downvotes already, jump on opportunities to bury a post, or simply bot peoples' posts with downvotes, and meanwhile it's possible that the author (on their platform) doesn't see the downvotes (only "likes" i.e.  upvotes), causing a sea of confusion in the post's replies. It could also actively demotivate people from wanting to post on ATP because they're scared of getting negative scores on their timelines.

Imagine you make a post and see a bunch of likes on your client of choice (because you prefer posting on a platform with Likes rather than downvotes), but on another platform your posts are also indexed, with downvotes counted. One platform shows "100 likes" and the other platform shows "-123 votes" and people start replying "lol everybody disagrees with your opinion" and/or posting screenshots of negative scores. You wouldn't understand what's happening ("why is my score x on client A but y on client B?"), leaving you confused and simultaneously on the receiving end of controversial replies and negative voting behavior.

It could also cause competitors to constantly try to manipulate other parties' posts' exposure with botted downvotes, trying to influence public opinion and create a negative connotation about their competition.

I'm not saying upvotes + downvotes are inherently bad for all types of platforms. It works for e.g. Reddit, but replacing Likes with Upvotes/Downvotes on a social networking standard/protocol *will* cause an extreme shift of direction for the protocol and I would no longer consider it as a decentralized version of Twitter-like networking.

This decision will likely cause the content and manner of communication on ATP to have more properties of a Reddit front page + comment section rather than a Twitter timeline/replies section. The respective purposes of posts/clients/indexers that count upvotes exclusively (as "likes") and ones that use an Upvotes/Downvotes scheme are so incredibly different that they might as well belong to two different protocols.

comment.body: Note that likes/upboats/downvotes/etc arent “in the protocol”. They are a particular type of interaction defined by a particular lexicon. The downvotes you see in the repo are defined in the app.bsky lexicon, which is a twitter-like system built on the AT protocol. One lexicon including downvotes doesnt mean everything using atproto has downvotes.

issue.title: Auth checks must happen before any other work
issue.body: Currently we are validating schemas (potentially expensive work) before checking auth. This opens us up to additional DoS vectors that we shouldn't allow.

issue.title: Handler errors if Content-Type is set to json during Query calls
issue.body: Query methods with no request body will error out of the Content-Type header is set. I would expect it to just be ignored

issue.title: Bearer API prefix is confusing

labels.name: New Feature
labels.description: Issues that we will work on with people or ourselves

issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
I find it really confusing, especially to new users that the API KEY needs to have "Bearer " prefix when making requests

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Short patch of code that detects the api key is of the form "EST-xxx-ARY" instead of "Bearer EST-xxx-ARY" and just accepts either

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Alternative would be to remove the Bearer at all - but that would break things for users

**Additional context**
I have a PR ready i'll link in

comment.body: This is HTTP standard stuff, The authorization header is intended to have a specific format, see: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Authorization

issue.title: request body sizes need to be limited
issue.body: It currently seems like request body sizes are unbounded, We should put some limits here both at the http server layer and at the nginx layer.

payload.description: Some bluesky code
Some bluesky code

issue.title: Add varint encoding of code to table
issue.body:
For a large number of usecases people need to varint encode the multicodec value before making use of it, it might be useful to add that alongside the code in another column.
The failure mode i've observed recently is someone taking the hex for the multicodec, writing it down as bytes, and being confused when things don't line up.

a hopefully fast file syncing tool

issue.title: [wip] Data Explorer
issue.body:
Simple tool for exploring data on the network (+some fixes to lotus retrieval to make it work + retrieval into remote blockstore APIs).

I was chiseling at this in random spare moments for a while now, things got to the point where this can be an actually useful tool.

TBD if we want to land this into the lotus repo, or have it live in a separate place.

Some major issues it has / revealed:
* Range matchers on unixfs dags don't seem to fetch all the needed blocks
* Same with just reinterp-unixfs->match selectors 
* Markets only allow a single parallel retrieval per pieceCid/miner, even with different selectors
* No way to write a selector which matches a HAMT directory without fetching 1 level of children nodes
* All data is temporarily held in an in-memory blockstore
* Many, many miners have broken dagstore indexes (retrievals run into `failed to lookup index for mh [...], err: datastore: key not found`)
* cid.contact seems to be missing majority of cids stored by miners

Running:
* Have a lotus (or lotus --lite) node running (**using this branch**)
* `make dataexpl`
* `./dataexpl run`
* Open http://127.0.0.1:5658

Some of the features:
* Go through miners in the market actor:
![obraz](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3867941/192524021-185210f0-0f02-42e3-b676-e659a97c40f4.png)

* Display miner sectors/deals
![obraz](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3867941/192524352-4a8c6475-29ac-4fe1-bec8-2624898018fb.png)

* Display deal info
![obraz](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3867941/192524439-e592e7d3-71ad-4a02-b939-f7e3c32b3ecd.png)

* Explore IPLD
  * Raw blocks
![obraz](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3867941/192528933-508b4a22-3771-45bf-8f26-259f6f754f44.png)

  * Dag-cbor (eg this Filecoin actor amt)
![obraz](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3867941/192529237-fd14c2e8-c859-41fd-b05d-baf97b53d303.png)

  * Dag-pb
![obraz](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3867941/192529732-9161683c-4611-4aaf-9eda-e0110e89241b.png)

* Explore ipfs/unixfs
![obraz](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3867941/192530172-c2181754-68da-4a9e-b2d8-8292c80fe239.png)

* cid.contact integration
![obraz](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3867941/192532158-77c13cdc-912c-4f2d-b238-6dace99e9261.png)

comment.body: this is super cool

issue.body:
**Edit** There has been extensive discussion about this topic in the Matrix and I think the core team is on the same wavelength with the concerns described below, though the direction remains unclear.

I noticed that likes in the protocol were recently replaced with upvotes/downvotes. This could completely change the purpose and direction of the protocol in a way that makes it no longer viable as a decentralized Twitter-like network.

Visually representing a voting score would cause malicious interactions and sheep-like behavior (i.e. downvoting a post just because it's trending towards a negative score).

In the matrix channel there was a reply saying it's up to the client application to work with downvotes if they choose. The problem with this is it would cause a discrepancy with how likes/votes are displayed per client (i.e. one shows the `upvoteCount` as Likes while another shows a positive or negative score based on total upvotes and downvotes accumulated) thus cause constant confusion.

People will make troll replies/downvotes when they see a post that has a lot of downvotes already, jump on opportunities to bury a post, or simply bot peoples' posts with downvotes, and meanwhile it's possible that the author (on their platform) doesn't see the downvotes (only "likes" i.e.  upvotes), causing a sea of confusion in the post's replies. Imagine you make a post and see a bunch of likes on your client of choice (because you prefer posting on a platform with Likes rather than downvotes), but on another platform your posts are also indexed, with downvotes counted. One platform shows "100 likes" and the other platform shows "-123 votes" and people start replying "lol everybody disagrees with your opinion" and/or posting screenshots of negative scores. You wouldn't understand what's happening ("why is my score x on client A but y on client B?"), leaving you confused and simultaneously on the receiving end of controversial replies and negative voting behavior.

This decision will likely cause the content and manner of communication on ATP to have more properties of a Reddit front page + comment section rather than a Twitter timeline/replies section. issue.body:
Two more Lexicon updates to accommodate stricter programming languages:

- LexXrpcBody `.encoding` is now always a `string`. If multiple encodings must be specified, use a comma-separated list.
- Union discriminators
  - The `union` type now only supports object-values with a `$type` field.
  - The `$type` field must specify the lexicon ID being used.
  - The `union` def now has a `closed` field which, if true, will fail validation if a `$type` is provided which does not match the enumerated refs.

comment.body: oooooh, so its implicit now? i see

issue.title: Lexicon tweaks: encoding and union $type discriminators
issue.body:
Two more Lexicon updates to accommodate stricter programming languages:

- LexXrpcBody `.encoding` is now always a `string`. If multiple encodings must be specified, use a comma-separated list.
- Union discriminators
  - The `union` type now only supports object-values with a `$type` field.
  - The `$type` field must specify the lexicon ID being used.
  - The `union` def now has a `closed` field which, if true, will fail validation if a `$type` is provided which does not match the enumerated refs.

issue.title: Misc Lexicon issues
issue.body:
In working on lexicon codegen i've come across a number of weird potential-bugs:

- com.atproto.sync.getRepo has its output type as cbor, but the output is actually a car file
- notification.updateSeen has output type defined with an encoding but no type definition
- repo.batchWrite has a oneOf schema definition that has inlined type declarations instead of using defs. This might be okay, but its the only place this occurs (and i've lazily assumed its the rule)
- The following lexicons have improperly defined input or output types:
  - account.delete
  - account.get
  - repo.batchWrite
  - session.delete

issue.title: Likes got replaced by Upvotes/Downvotes
issue.body:
**Edit** There has been extensive discussion about this topic in the Matrix and I think the core team is on the same wavelength with the concerns described below, though the direction remains unclear.

I noticed that likes in the protocol were recently replaced with upvotes/downvotes. This could completely change the purpose and direction of the protocol in a way that makes it no longer viable as a decentralized Twitter-like network.

Tldr: imagine every tweet you make also becomes a Reddit thread, and every reply also shows up in a Reddit comment section.

Upvotes and downvotes will make ATP more fit for reddit-esque discussion boards rather than timeline-based social networking/microblogging. Visually representing a voting score would cause malicious interactions and sheep-like behavior (i.e. downvoting a post just because it's trending towards a negative score).

In the matrix channel there was a reply saying it's up to the client application to work with downvotes if they choose. The problem with this is it would cause a discrepancy with how likes/votes are displayed per client (i.e. one shows the `upvoteCount` as Likes while another shows a positive or negative score based on total upvotes and downvotes accumulated) thus cause constant confusion.

People will make troll replies/downvotes when they see a post that has a lot of downvotes already, jump on opportunities to bury a post, or simply bot peoples' posts with downvotes, and meanwhile it's possible that the author (on their platform) doesn't see the downvotes (only "likes" i.e.  upvotes), causing a sea of confusion in the post's replies. It could also actively demotivate people from wanting to post on ATP because they're scared of getting negative scores on their timelines.

Imagine you make a post and see a bunch of likes on your client of choice (because you prefer posting on a platform with Likes rather than downvotes), but on another platform your posts are also indexed, with downvotes counted. One platform shows "100 likes" and the other platform shows "-123 votes" and people start replying "lol everybody disagrees with your opinion" and/or posting screenshots of negative scores. You wouldn't understand what's happening ("why is my score x on client A but y on client B?"), leaving you confused and simultaneously on the receiving end of controversial replies and negative voting behavior.

It could also cause competitors to constantly try to manipulate other parties' posts' exposure with botted downvotes, trying to influence public opinion and create a negative connotation about their competition.

I'm not saying upvotes + downvotes are inherently bad for all types of platforms. It works for e.g. Reddit, but replacing Likes with Upvotes/Downvotes on a social networking standard/protocol *will* cause an extreme shift of direction for the protocol and I would no longer consider it as a decentralized version of Twitter-like networking.

This decision will likely cause the content and manner of communication on ATP to have more properties of a Reddit front page + comment section rather than a Twitter timeline/replies section. The respective purposes of posts/clients/indexers that count upvotes exclusively (as "likes") and ones that use an Upvotes/Downvotes scheme are so incredibly different that they might as well belong to two different protocols.

comment.body: Note that likes/upboats/downvotes/etc arent “in the protocol”. They are a particular type of interaction defined by a particular lexicon. The downvotes you see in the repo are defined in the app.bsky lexicon, which is a twitter-like system built on the AT protocol. One lexicon including downvotes doesnt mean everything using atproto has downvotes.

issue.title: Handler errors if Content-Type is set to json during Query calls
issue.body: Query methods with no request body will error out of the Content-Type header is set. I would expect it to just be ignored

issue.title: Bearer API prefix is confusing

labels.name: New Feature
labels.description: Issues that we will work on with people or ourselves

issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
I find it really confusing, especially to new users that the API KEY needs to have "Bearer " prefix when making requests

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Short patch of code that detects the api key is of the form "EST-xxx-ARY" instead of "Bearer EST-xxx-ARY" and just accepts either

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Alternative would be to remove the Bearer at all - but that would break things for users

**Additional context**
I have a PR ready i'll link in

comment.body: This is HTTP standard stuff, The authorization header is intended to have a specific format, see: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Authorization

issue.title: request body sizes need to be limited
issue.body: It currently seems like request body sizes are unbounded, We should put some limits here both at the http server layer and at the nginx layer.

issue.title: Add varint encoding of code to table
issue.body:
For a large number of usecases people need to varint encode the multicodec value before making use of it, it might be useful to add that alongside the code in another column.
The failure mode i've observed recently is someone taking the hex for the multicodec, writing it down as bytes, and being confused when things don't line up.

issue.title: [wip] Data Explorer
issue.body:
Simple tool for exploring data on the network (+some fixes to lotus retrieval to make it work + retrieval into remote blockstore APIs).

I was chiseling at this in random spare moments for a while now, things got to the point where this can be an actually useful tool.

TBD if we want to land this into the lotus repo, or have it live in a separate place.

Some major issues it has / revealed:
* Range matchers on unixfs dags don't seem to fetch all the needed blocks
* Same with just reinterp-unixfs->match selectors 
* Markets only allow a single parallel retrieval per pieceCid/miner, even with different selectors
* No way to write a selector which matches a HAMT directory without fetching 1 level of children nodes
* All data is temporarily held in an in-memory blockstore
* Many, many miners have broken dagstore indexes (retrievals run into `failed to lookup index for mh [...], err: datastore: key not found`)
* cid.contact seems to be missing majority of cids stored by miners

Running:
* Have a lotus (or lotus --lite) node running (**using this branch**)
* `make dataexpl`
* `./dataexpl run`
* Open http://127.0.0.1:5658

Some of the features:
* Go through miners in the market actor:
![obraz](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3867941/192524021-185210f0-0f02-42e3-b676-e659a97c40f4.png)

* Display miner sectors/deals
![obraz](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3867941/192524352-4a8c6475-29ac-4fe1-bec8-2624898018fb.png)

* Display deal info
![obraz](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3867941/192524439-e592e7d3-71ad-4a02-b939-f7e3c32b3ecd.png)

* Explore IPLD
  * Raw blocks
![obraz](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3867941/192528933-508b4a22-3771-45bf-8f26-259f6f754f44.png)

  * Dag-cbor (eg this Filecoin actor amt)
![obraz](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3867941/192529237-fd14c2e8-c859-41fd-b05d-baf97b53d303.png)

  * Dag-pb
![obraz](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3867941/192529732-9161683c-4611-4aaf-9eda-e0110e89241b.png)

* Explore ipfs/unixfs
![obraz](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3867941/192530172-c2181754-68da-4a9e-b2d8-8292c80fe239.png)

* cid.contact integration
![obraz](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3867941/192532158-77c13cdc-912c-4f2d-b238-6dace99e9261.png)

comment.body: this is super cool
